paragraphs: 7\bHongji-dong,\bJongno-gu,\bSeoul\b110-743,\bKorea\b ihlee@smu.ac.kr\b Abstract.\b This\b \fa\fer\b investigates\b some\b resultative\b constructions\b in\b English,\b Korean,\b Chinese,\band\bJa\fanese.\bIt\bwill\bbe\bargued\bthat\bthe\bDirect\bObject\bRestriction\b(DOR)\bused\bin\b \frevious\b syntactic\b accounts\b is\b not\b correct.\b This\b \fa\fer\b examines\b the\b ty\fical\b resultative\b constructions\bin\bEnglish\band\bKorean\band,\bwithin\bthe\bframework\bof\bevent\bsemantics,\boffers\ba\b \fro\fer\bsemantic\baccount\bof\bthe\brelevant\bdata\bon\bthe\bbasis\bof\bthe\bsemantic\brelationshi\fs\bof\bthe\b lexical\bitems.\bThe\banalysis\bmakes\buse\bof\bthe\bnotions\bsuch\bas\b‘event,’\b‘a\f\fro\friate\bresult,’\betc.\b In\baddition,\bit\bwill\bbe\bshown\bthat\bthe\b\fro\fosed\baccount\bis\balso\buseful\bfor\bex\flaining\bthe\bsocalled\bresultative\bVerb-Verb\bCom\founds\b(VVCs)\bin\bKorean,\bChinese,\band\bJa\fanese.\b\b Keyw\frds:\bcom\flex\b\fredicate,\bverb-verb\bcom\found\b(VVC),\bcausal,\ba\f\fro\friate,\baffected\b

sections.title: 1 Resultat\b\te \ts. Dep\bct\b\te Sentences
paragraphs: Jes\fersen\b(1909-49,\bPart\bV:\b23-28)\bdiscusses\bthe\bty\fe\bof\bsentence\bin\b(1)\bunder\bthe\bterm\b‘object\b of\b result’.\b \tater\b Halliday\b (1967:63-65)\b discusses\b a\b similar\b ty\fe\b of\b sentence\b in\b (2a)\b using\b the\b term\b‘resultative,’\bwhich\bhe\bcom\fares\bwith\banother\bsentence\b\fattern\b‘de\fictive’\bin\b(2b).\b (1) \b He\b\fushed\bthe\bgate\bopen.\b (2) \b a.\bShe\bwashes\bthem\bclean.\b(resultative)\b

=\bShe\bsells\bthem\band,\bwhen\bshe\bsells\bthem,\bthey\bare\bchea\f.\b Sim\fson\b(1983:143)\brecognizes\bfour\bty\fes\bof\bresultatives,\band\bshe\bclaims\bthat\bthe\bmatrix\bverb\b and\bthe\bresultative\b\fhrase\bform\ba\bcom\flex\bverb.\bThe\bresultative\b\fhrases\bare\bdiverse\band\bthey\bare\b collectively\b termed\b result\b ‘XPs’\b (Hovav\b and\b \tevin,\b 2001:766)\b or\b ‘RPs’\b (Goldberg\b and\b Jackendoff,\b2004:536).\bI\bwill\buse\bthe\babbreviation\bRP\bin\bthis\b\fa\fer.\b Recent\b researchers\b on\b English\b resultatives\b (Wechsler,\b 1997;\b Kaufmann\b and\b Wunderlich,\b 1998;\bHovav\band\b\tevin,\b2001;\bGoldberg\band\bJackendoff,\b2004)\bhave\bcollected\bdata\bof\bvarious\b resultative\b constructions\b and\b focused\b on\b the\b ty\fical\b sentences\b listed\b in\b (3).\b Following\b the\b general\bconvention\b(in\b\farticular,\bWechsler,\b1997),\bthe\bresult\b\fhrase\b(RP)\bis\bitalicized\band\bthe\b NP\bof\bwhich\bthe\bRP\bis\b\fredicated\bis\bunderlined.\b (3) \b a.\bHe\bhammered\bthe\bmetal\b\bla\t.\b(RP=Adjective\bPhrase)\b[Object-\fredicated]\b

[Object-\fredicated,\bbut\bactually\bSubject-\fredicated]\b \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\r\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b * \b I\bwould\blike\bto\bthank\bmy\bcolleague\bMinhaeng\b\tee\bat\bYonsei\bUniversity\bfor\b\froviding\bme\bwith\bim\fortant\b\fa\fers\b on\bresultatives\band\bhel\fful\bcomments\bon\bthe\bcontents\bof\bthis\b\fa\fer.\bAny\bremaining\bmistakes,\bhowever,\bare\ball\bmy\b own.\b\b \b In\b this\b \fa\fer\b the\b following\b abbreviations\b are\b used:\b Acc=Accusative\b \farticle,\b As\f=As\fect\b marker,\b Com\f=Com\flementizer,\b Dat=Dative,\b Dec=Declarative\b \farticle,\b De=Resultative\b marker,\b \toc=\tocative,\b Ni=Directional\b \fost\fosition,\b Nom=Nominative\b \farticle,\b Past=Past\b tense\b marker,\b Perf=Perfective\b marker,\b Poss=Possessive\b marker,\b Pres=Present\b tense\b marker,\b To\f=To\fic\b \farticle,\b Vi=Intransitive\b verb,\b Tv=Transitive\b verb.\b \b \b Co\fyright\b2009\bby\bIk-Hwan\b\tee\b 29 23rd Pacific Asia Conference on Language, Information and Computation, pages 29–39 \b

In\b (3a)\b the\b result\b \fhrase(RP),\b an\b adjective,\b\bla\t\b is\b \fredicated\b of\b the\b direct\b object\b NP\b\t\fe me\tal,\band\bin\b(3b)\bthe\bRP,\ban\bNP,\ba pale s\fade o\b red,\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bdirect\bobject\bNP\b\t\fe car.\bIn\b(3c)\bthe\bRP\bsolid\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bsurface\bmatrix\bsubject\b\t\fe brook\bof\bthe\bintransitive\b unaccusative\bconstruction.\bIn\b(3d)\bthe\bRP\b\foarse\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bmatrix\bsubject\b\fe\bthrough\b the\b\fostverbal\breflexive\b\fimsel\b.\bIn\bthis\bcase,\bhowever,\bwe\bmay\bsay\bthat\bthe\bRP\bsyntactically\bis\b \fredicated\bof\bthe\breflexive\bobject\b\fimsel\b.\bIn\b(3e)\bthe\bRP\bdry\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bdirect\bobject\b \t\fe pub.\bFinally,\bin\b(3f)\bthe\bRP,\bou\t o\b \t\fe room,\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bmatrix\bsubject\bMary.\b\b

sections.title: 2 Syntact\bc Acc\funt and Its Pr\fblems
paragraphs: As\bnoted\bby\bHovav\band\b\tevin\b(2001:766),\bthe\bsuccess\bof\bsyntactic\baccounts\bis\bmainly\bdue\bto\bthe\b Unaccusative\bHy\fothesis\b(Perlmutter,\b1978,\bUH\bhenceforth).\bIntransitive\bverbs\bin\bEnglish\bhas\b two\b subclasses:\b unaccusative\b verbs\b and\b unergative\b verbs.\b The\b unaccusative\b hy\fothesis\b claims\b that\b the\b argument\b of\b an\b unaccusative\b verb\b is\b an\b internal\b direct\b argument,\b while\b the\b only\b argument\bof\ban\bunergative\bverb\bis\ban\bexternal\bargument.\bIt\bhas\bbeen\bargued\bthat\bthe\binternal\bor\b external\bstatus\bof\bthe\barguments\bof\bunaccusative\band\bunergative\bverbs\bis\ba\bsyntactic\bfact.\bIt\bhas\b also\bbeen\bargued\bthat\bresult\b\fhrases\b(RPs)\bin\bEnglish\bare\b\fredicated\bof\bNPs\bin\bobject\b\fosition\b (Sim\fson\b1983).\bThis\bis\bthe\bso-called\bDirect\bObject\bRestriction\b(DOR,\bhenceforth).\b

The\bDOR\baccounts\bfor\bthe\btransitive\bresultative\bin\b(3a),\bthe\bunaccusative\bresultative\bin\b(3c),\b and\bthe\bso-called\b‘fake\breflexive’\bresultative\bin\b(3d).\bThe\bUH\b\fosits\ban\bunderlying\bobject\bfor\bthe\b subject\b of\b an\b unaccusative\b verb\b in\b (3c).\b In\b (3c)\b the\b surface\b subject\b\t\fe brook is\b actually\b re\fresented\bas\ban\bunderlying\bobject.\bThe\bDOR\bis\bassumed\bto\ba\f\fly\bon\bthe\bunderlying\blevel\band\b ex\flain\bthe\bconstruction.\bThus,\bthe\bDOR\baccounts\bfor\bthe\btransitive\bresultative\bin\b(3a)\band\bthe\b unaccusative\bconstruction\bin\b(3c)\bas\bwell.\b\b

In\baddition,\bthe\bDOR\bmay\baccount\bfor\bthe\bfake\breflexive\bconstruction\bin\b(3d).\bThe\breflexive\b \fronoun\bis\bin\bthe\bobject\b\fosition,\band\bit\bsatisfies\bthe\bDOR\bbecause\bthe\bRP\b\foarse\bseems\bto\bbe\b \fredicated\b of\b the\b reflexive\b object.\b However,\b the\b reflexive\b may\b not\b a\f\fear\b alone\b as\b the\b ungrammaticality\b of\b the\b sentences\b in\b (4)\b shows.\bThis\b fact\b indicates\b that\b the\b RP\b in\b (3d)\b is\b actually\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bsubject\bJo\fn,\bindirectly\bthrough\bthe\bana\fhoric\breflexive\b\fronoun.\b (4) \b a.\b*John\byelled\bhimself.\b

However,\bthe\bDOR\bused\bin\b\frevious\bsyntactic\baccounts\bhas\bsome\b\froblems.\bIn\bEnglish\bthere\b are\bsentences\bwith\btransitive\bverbs,\bin\bwhich\bthe\bRP\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\bsubjects,\bnot\bobjects.\bIn\b these\bconstructions\bthe\bDOR\bis\bviolated.\bThe\bexam\fles\bin\b(5)\bare\btaken\bfrom\bHovav\band\b\tevin\b (2001:770).\bThe\boriginal\bsource\bof\beach\bsentence\bis\bgiven\bin\b\farentheses.\b (5) \b a.\bThe\bwise\bmen\bfollowed\bthe\bstar\bou\t o\b Be\t\fle\fem.\b(Wechsler,\b1997:313)\b \b \b \b \b b.\bJohn\bdanced\bmazurkas\bacross \t\fe room.\b(Vers\foor,\b1997:151)\b \b \b \b \b c.\bFly\bAmerican\bAirlines\b\to Hawaii for\byour\bvacation!\b(Hovav\b&\b\tevin,\b2001:770)\b In\b these\b exam\fles,\b the\b RPs\b are\b \fredicated\b of\b the\b subjects;\b hence,\b they\b belong\b to\b the\b subjectoriented\btransitive-based\b\fattern\bin\bHovav\band\b\tevin’s\bterm\b(2001:770).\b\b

sections.title: 3 Semant\bc Acc\funt
paragraphs: Wechsler\b (1997:309)\b notes\b that\b the\b relation\b between\b the\b matrix\b Verb\b and\b the\b RP\b must\b be\b ‘canonical’\bor\b‘normal’\bto\bmake\bu\f\ban\bacce\ftable\bcombination.\bFollowing\bthis\bidea,\bHovav\band\b \tevin\b(2001:774-775)\bex\flain\bthe\bresultative\b\fatterns\bin\bterms\bof\bthe\bsemantic\brelation\bbetween\b the\bevent\bdenoted\bby\bthe\bverb\band\bthe\bevent\bre\fresented\bby\bthe\bresult\b RP.\b Accordingly,\b it\b has\b usually\bbeen\bassumed\bthat\bthe\bVerb-RP\bcombination\bre\fresents\ba\bcom\flex\bevent\bconsisting\bof\b two\bsubevents.\b\b
A\b formal\b rule\b of\b resultative\b formation\b is\b found\b in\b Kaufmann\b and\b Wunderlich\b (1998:6),\b which\bgives\ba\bsimilar\bfinal\bre\fresentation.\b\b

In\b(8a),\bWipe-cleaning'(e)\b is\b a\b com\flex\b event\b denoted\b by\b the\b semantic\b com\flex\b \fredicate\b wipe-clean.\bThis\bwi\fe-clean\bevent\bconsists\bof\btwo\bsubevents,\bthe\bfirst\bof\bwhich,\bWiping'\b(e1),\bis\b the\bcausing\bevent\bof\bthe\bcom\flex\bevent(e),\bwhile\bthe\bsecond\bone,\bClean'\b(e2)\bis\ba\bresult\bevent.\b Cause(e1,e)\bmeans\bthat\bthe\be1\bis\bthe\b causing\b event\b of\b the\b com\flex\b event\b e,\b while\b Result\b (e2,e)\b shows\bthat\be2\bis\ba\bresult\bstate\bof\be.\bWiping'\b(e1)\bis\ban\bactivity\bevent,\bwhile\bClean'\b(e2)\bis\ba\bstate\b event.\bThe\blast\b\fart\b‘A\f\fro\friate-Result(e2,e1)’\b,\bwhich\bis\ba\bnew\baddition\bin\bthe\b\fresent\b\fa\fer,\b means\bthat\be2\bis\ban\ba\f\fro\friate\bresult\bof\be1.\bThis\b\fart\bensures\bthe\bacce\ftable\bcombination\bof\bthe\b verbal\band\bresult\b\fhrases.\bI\bsti\fulate\bthis\bas\ba\bsemantic/\fragmatic\bconstrain.\b

sections.title: 4 Semant\bc/Pragmat\bc C\fnstran\bts
paragraphs: Wechsler\b (1997:311)\b notes\b that,\b in\b resultatives,\b the\b normal\b result\b state\b of\b a\b main\b verb\b can\b be\b decided\bon\bthe\bbasis\bof\bthe\bsemantic\b\fro\ferties\bof\badjectives,\bas\bde\ficted\bin\b(9).\b (9) \b a.\bJohn\bhammered\bthe\bmetal\b\bla\t/\bsmoo\t\f/\b(?)s\finy/\bin\to \t\fe ground/\b*beau\ti\bul/\b*sa\be.\b \b \b \b \b b.\bSally\b\fainted\bthe\bdoor\bred/\ba pale s\fade o\b red/\b?s\ticky/\b*beau\ti\bul/\b*no\ticeable.\b 31 \b In\b (9a),\b the\b com\flex\b lexical\b \fredicate\b\fammer-\bla\t\b is\b a\b ‘normal’\b relation,\b while\b the\b RPs\b beau\ti\bul\b or\bno\ticeable\b are\b not\b inherent\b consequences\b of\b the\b hammering\b activities.\b A\b similar\b observation\b can\b be\b made\b about\b the\b exam\fles\b in\b (9b).\b I\b take\b this\b restriction\b as\b the\b a\f\fro\friate\b result\bconstraint.\bThe\bexam\fles\bin\b(9)\bmay\bbe\bre\fresented\bin\bterms\bof\bthe\ba\f\fro\friate\brelations\b as\bin\b(10).\bThe\bstarred\bone\billustrates\ba\brelation\bwhich\bis\bnot\binherent.\b\b (10) \b a.\bpain\t-red,\bpain\t-a pale s\fade o\b red,\b*pain\t-beau\ti\bul,\b*pain\t-no\ticeable\b \b \b \b \b \b b.\b\fammer-\bla\t,\b\fammer-smoo\t\f,\b*\fammer-beau\ti\bul,\b*\fammer-sa\be\b

I\bwill\bsti\fulate\bthis\brelation\bas\ba\bconstraint,\bnamely\ban\bA\f\fro\friate\bResult\bConstraint\b(ARC)\b as\bin\b(15c)\bbelow.\bThe\bconstraint\bwill\bhave\ba\bsimilar\beffect\bas\bWechsler’s\b(1997:311)\bCanonical\b Result\bRestriction\b(CRR),\bwhich\bsays\bthat\b“a\bcontrol\bresultative\bmust\bre\fresent\ba\b‘canonical’\bor’\b normal’\b result\b state\b of\b an\b action\b denoted\b by\b the\b verb.”\b My\b ARC,\b however,\b is\b more\b com\frehensive\b in\b that\b it\b a\f\flies\b to\b all\b the\b resultative\b constructions\b including\b Verb-Verb\b com\founds\b (VVC)\b in\b languages\b such\b as\b Korean,\b Ja\fanese,\b and\b Chinese,\b while\b Wechsler’s\b CRR\bis\blimited\bto\bthe\bcontrol\bresultatives\bmainly\bin\bEnglish.\b\b

\b b.\bThe\bwater\bfroze\bsolid.\b In\b (11)\b the\b subject\bJo\fn\b is\b not\b affected\b by\b the\b matrix\b verb\b\fammer,\b so\b it\b cannot\b be\b the\b \fredication\bsubject\bof\bthe\bRP\bex\faus\ted.\bIn\b(12a),\bthe\bdirect\bobject\b\t\fe me\tal\bis\baffected\bby\bthe\b matrix\bverb\b\fammer,\bso\bit\bis\bthe\b\fredication\bsubject.\bIn\b(12b),\bthe\bsubject\b\t\fe wa\ter\bis\baffected\b by\bthe\bmatrix\bverb\b\breeze,\bthus\bit\bis\bthe\b\fredication\bsubject\bof\bthe\bRP\bsolid.\b

\b\b\b\b\bWechsler’s\bATR\bworks\bfine\bfor\bthe\bcounterexam\fles\bto\bthe\bDOR,\bgiven\bin\b(13).\b (13) \b a.\bMary\bdanced\bou\t o\b \t\fe room.\b \b \b \b \b \b b.\bThe\bwise\bmen\bfollowed\bthe\bstar\bou\t o\b Be\t\fle\fem.\b The\bexam\fles\bin\b(13a,b)\bare\bcounterexam\fles\bto\bthe\bDOR\bbecause\bthe\bRPs\bare\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\b subjects,\bnot\bdirect\bobjects.\bAccording\bto\bWechsler’s\bATR,\bhowever,\bthe\bsubjects\bcan\bbe\btreated\b as\baffected\bthemes.\bThus,\bthe\bsemantic\bATR\bis\b\froved\bto\bbe\bmore\beffective\bthan\b the\b syntactic\b DOR.\bHowever,\bthe\bATR\bis\bnot\bquite\buseful\bin\bKorean,\bas\bshown\bin\b(14).\b\b (14) \b a.\b\bku-nun\b\b[os-\b\b\b\beyse\b\bkim-i\b\b\b\b\bna-key]\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\bttwi-ess-ta.\b \b \b \b \b \b \b \b he-To\f\b\b\bclothes-\toc\b\bsteam-Nom\bcome\bout-Com\f]\brun-Past-Dec\b \b \b \b \b \b \b \b ‘He\bran\b(his)\bshirts\bsteaming.’\b\b \b \b \b \b \b b.\b\bku-nun\b[\fal-ey\b\b\b\bmulci\f-i\b\b\bsayngki-key]\b\b\bkel-ess-ta.\b \b \b \b \b \b \b \b he-To\f\b\b\bfeet-\toc\b\bblister-Nom\bcome\bout-Com\f\bwalk-Past-Dec\b \b \b \b \b \b \b \b ‘He\bwalked\bhis\bfoot\bblistered.’\b It\bis\bclaimed\bthat\bin\bthe\bexam\fles\bin\b(14a)\bthe\bRP\bkim-i na\b‘steam’\bis\b\fredicated\bof\bthe\blocative\b arguments\b (\toc)\bos-eyse\b ‘clothes-\toc’.\b Similarly,\b also\b in\b (14b),\b the\b RP\b is\b \fredicated\b of\b the\b locative\b argument\b (J.\b Kim,\b 1997).\b Accordingly,\b in\b our\b \frevious\b \fa\fer\b (\tee,\b Kim,\b and\b \tee,\b 2004:135),\b we\b noted\b that\b the\b ATR\b should\b not\b adhere\b to\b the\b ‘themehood’\b but\b to\b the\b ‘affectedness’\bonly.\bThis\bfact\bis\bincor\forated\bin\bthe\brevised\brestriction\bAAC\bgiven\bin\b(15d).1

\b\b\b\b\bTaking\b these\b observations\b into\b consideration,\b I\b formulate\b the\b semantic/\fragmatic\b conditions\bon\bthe\brelationshi\f\bbetween\ba\bverbal\bevent\band\ba\bresult\bevent\bas\bin\b(15).\b

\b\b In\bEnglish\bthe\bnotion\bof\b‘affectedness’\bwas\bdiscussed\bby\bCroft\b(1991:170)\bin\bterms\bof\b‘force\btransmission’\band\b later\bHovav\band\b\tevin\b(2001:786)\bnote\bthat\b“in\bsubcategorized\bNP\bresultatives\bthe\bresult\bXP\bmust\bbe\b\fredicated\b of\b the\b argument\b of\b the\b verb\b that\b is\b the\b force\b reci\fient,\b if\b there\b is\b one.”\b They\b also\b say\b that\b force\b reci\fients\b sometimes\b may\b not\b be\b \fatients,\b which\b include\b themes.\b This\b means\b that\b non-themes\b may\b be\b force\b reci\fients,\b which\bare\barguments\bthat\bthe\bresult\bRP\bmay\bbe\b\fredicated\bof.\b 32
(15) \b Restrictions\bon\bresultatives\b a. Shared\b Argument\b Constraint\b (SAC):\b At\b least\b one\b of\b the\b arguments\b of\b the\b event\b
argument\bof\bthe\bresult\bevent.\b\b b. Causal\b Relation\b Constraint\b (CRC):\b The\b two\b subevents\b of\b a\b resultative\b are\b causally\b
related.\b c. A\f\fro\friate\b Result\b Constraint\b (ARC):\b The\b result\b subevent\b denoted\b by\b the\b V2\b of\b a\b
resultative\b is\b a\b semantically\b and/or\b \fragmatically\b a\f\fro\friate\b result\b of\b the\b subevent\b
According\bto\b\tee,\bKim,\band\b\tee\b(2004),\ban\bECM\b resultative\b in\b German\b like\b (16a)\b has\b the\b

e2\b[Result\b(e2,e)\b&\bClean'\b(e2)\b&\b\tocative\b(the\blawn',e2)]\b \b \b\b \b \b \b \b &\bA\f\fro\friate-Result(e2,e1)\b&\b[e1\b<\be2])\b\b In\b(8b),\b Section\b 3,\b the\b affected\b argument\b is\b a\b theme\b as\b the\b ex\fression\b ‘Theme(the\b table',e1)’\b shows,\b while\b in\b (16b)\b it\b is\b a\b locative\b argument\b as\b the\b ex\fression\b ‘\tocative(the\b lawn',e1)’\b indicates.\b This\b is\b allowed\b by\b the\b constraint\b (15d),\b namely\b AAC.\b According\b to\b Washio’s\b (1997:438-440)\bclassification,\b(8a)\bis\ban\bexam\fle\bof\b‘weak\bresultative’,\bwhile\b(16a)\bis\ba\b‘strong\b resulative.’\bThe\bsemantic\bre\fresentations\b(8b)\band\b(16b)\bshow\bthat,\bonce\bthe\baffected\bargument\b is\b defined\b by\b the\b lexical\b semantics\b of\b the\b matrix\b verb,\b and\b the\b com\flex\b \fredicate\b V+RP\b is\b licensed,\b we\b do\b not\b need\b to\b have\b a\b distinction\b between\b the\b strong\b and\b weak\b resultatives\b in\b \froviding\bthe\bsemantic\bforms.\bOther\bECM\bexam\fles\bcan\balso\bbe\b\fro\ferly\btreated.\b

paragraphs: \fre\fositional\b\fro\ferty.\bThe\bty\fical\bexam\fles\bare\bgiven\bin\b(17).\b (17) \b a.\b Korean (S\tandard Dic\tionary o\b \t\fe Korean Language)\b
Sim\fson,\b 1983;\b Kaufmann,\b 1995;\b Kaufmann\b and\b Wunderlich,\b 1998;\b Wechsler,\b 1997;\b Hovav\b
and\b \tevin,\b 2001;\b Müller,\b 2002;\b Goldberg\b and\b Jackendoff,\b 2004),\b it\b has\b been\b \fersuasively\b
argued\b that\b the\b ‘Main\b Verb\b +\b RP’\b combination,\b e.g.\b\fammer-\bla\t,\b forms\b a\b kind\b of\b semantic\b
‘com\flex\b \fredicate’.\b This\b semantic\b com\flex\b \fredicate\b is\b actually\b syntactically\b realized\b in\b
Korean,\b Chinese,\b and\b Ja\fanese.\b That\b is,\b the\b Korean\b ex\fression\bkkwul-anc ‘kneel.down-sit’\b in\b

taken\bto\bconsist\bof\btwo\bverbs kkwul ‘kneel.down’\band anc ‘sit.’\bIt\bis\bim\fortant\bto\bnote\bthat\bin\bthe\b 33 \b exam\fle\b in\b (17a),\b no\b adverb\b can\b intervene\b between\bkkwul\b ‘kneel.down’\b and\banc\b ‘sit’.\b The\b exam\fles\bof\bChinese\band\bJa\fanese\bcan\bbe\banalyzed\bin\bthe\bsame\bway.\b\b Some\b claims\b that\b the\b Korean\b exam\fle\bkkwul-anc ‘kneel.down’\b is\b the\b contracted\b form\b of\b kkwul-e-anc ‘kneel.down.’\b S.\b \tee\b (2006:136-143)2

,\b however,\b convincingly\b argues\b against\b this\b claim.\b Without\b re\feating\b \tee’s\b argument\b here\b I\b assume\b that\bkkwul-anc\b ‘kneel.down-sit’\b is\b a\b \fure\b VVC\b in\b Korean.\b \tee\b \frovides\b similar\b exam\fles\b as\b in\b (18).\b I\b take\b more\b exam\fles\b from\b S\tandard Dic\tionary o\b \t\fe Korean Language\bcom\filed\bby\bthe\bNational\bInstitute\bof\bthe\bKorean\b \tanguage.\b (18) \b a.\b ku-nun\btol-ul\b\b\b\b\bkal-puswu-ess-ta.\b(Vt\b+\bVt)\b \b \b \b \b \b \b \b he-To\f\bcrystal-Acc\bgrind-smash-Past-Dec\b \b \b \b \b ‘He\bcrushed\bthe\bstone\bby\bgriding.=He\bground\bu\f\bthe\bstone’\b \b \b \b \b \b b.\b ku-nun\bswujeong-ul\bkal-\takk-ess-ta.\b[Vt\b+\bVt]\b \b \b \b \b he-To\f\bcrystal-Acc\brub-\folish-Past-Dec\b \b \b \b \b ‘He\b\folished\bthe\bcrystal\bby\brubbing.’\b In\bChinese\bthe\bcombination\bof\bVVCs\bis\bvery\b\froductive.\bThis\bmay\bbe\bdue\bto\bthe\bfact\bthat\bin\b some\b English\b unergative\b resultatives\b the\b fake\b reflexive\b is\b required,\b while\b it\b is\b not\b the\b case\b in\b Chinese.\bMany\bexam\fles\bare\bdiscussed\bin\brelevant\bworks\bon\bresultatives\bsuch\bas\bY.\b \ti(1990),\b Chung\b(1997),\bKaufmann\band\bWunderlich(1998),\bGamerschlag\b(2002),\bJ.\bHuang\b(2006),\betc.\b (19) \b Chinese\bExam\fles\b(Y.\b\ti,\b1990:\b177;\bJ.\bHuang,\b2006:15)\b

d.\bkam-ttwi\b‘walk.around-jum\f’\b With\bthese\bexam\fles\bin\b(20)\bwe\bcan\bargue\bagainst\bthe\bclaim\bthat\bthe\bserial\bverb\bconstructions\bin\b Korean\bare\bnot\bverb\bcom\founds\b(Zubizaretta\band\bOh,\b2007).\bMoreover,\bI\btake\bthe\bexam\fles\bin\b (17a),\b(18)\band\b(20)\bas\bresultative\bconstructions,\bso\bI\bclaim\bthat\bKorean\bhas\bresultative\bVVCs.\b Notice\b that\b these\b exam\fles\b have\b the\b \fro\ferties\b of\b the\b Korean\b serial\b verb\b constructions\b (Zubizaretta\b and\b Oh,\b 2007:57)\b and\b do\b not\b violate\b Y.\b \ti’s\b (1993:499)\b Tem\foral\b Iconicity\b Conditon\b (TIC).\b Also\b notice\b that,\b as\b the\b sentence\b in\b (21b)\b shows,\b there\b are\b no\b fake\b reflexive\b constructions\bin\bKorean.\bInstead,\bthe\bV-e-V\bconstructin\bin\bKorean\bcan\bbe\binter\freted\bas\ba\bkind\b of\bfake\breflexive\bresultative,\bas\bshown\bin\b(21a).\b (21) \b a.\b ku-nun\bttwi-e\b\b\bp\fikon\fa-ess-ta.\b

The\bverb\b\talli\b‘run’\bmay\bbe\bre\flaced\bby\bmal\fa\b‘say,\bs\feak’,\bnolay\fa\b‘sing’,\betc.\b Although\b there\b are\b several\b ty\fes\b of\b serial\b verb\b constructions\b in\b Korean,\b I\b will\b not\b discuss\b them\bin\bdetail\bhere.\b\b \b \b \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\r\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b 2 \b \bS.\b \tee\b (2006),\b first,\b classifies\b words\b into\b sim\fle\b words\b and\b com\flex\b words.\b He\b then\b divides\b the\b latter\b into\b

sections.title: 6 Semant\bc Analys\bs \ff Resultat\b\te VVCs
paragraphs: Some\bresearchers\bhave\btried\bto\b\frovide\ba\bsyntactic\baccount\bof\bthe\bVVCs\bin\blanguages\bsuch\bas\b Chinese,\bJa\fanese,\band\bKorean.\bAmong\bthem,\bY.\b\ti\b(1990)\b\fresents\ba\bsyntactic\bex\flanation\bof\b the\b Chinese\b VVCs\b in\b terms\b of\b the\bθ-grids\b of\b the\b \fartici\fating\b Vs,\b i.e.\b V1\b and\b V2,\b the\b headfeature\b \fercolation,\b and\b the\bθ-identification\b under\b the\b Government-Binding\b theory.\b In\b Y.\b \ti\b (1993),\b he\b extends\b his\b theory\b to\b the\b ex\flanation\b of\b the\b difference\b between\b Chinese,\b a\b headinitial\b language,\b and\b Ja\fanese,\b a\b head-final\b language.\b Chung\b (1997)\b notes\b that\b Korean\b VVCs\b are\bsimilar\bto\bJa\fanese.\bI\bagree\bwith\bhim.\b\b

Here,\bI\bwould\bnot\blike\bto\bgo\binto\bdetails\bof\btheir\bsyntactic\banalyses.\bOne\bthing\bI\bwant\bto\bnote\b is\b the\b fact\b that\b both\b of\b Y.\b \ti\b (1990,\b 1993)\b and\b Chung\b (1997)\b clearly\b mention\b the\b limits\b of\b syntactic\b ex\flanation.\b In\b a\b rather\b sim\fle\b resultative\b VVC,\b one\b of\b the\b \fossible\b argument\b combination\bty\fes\bis\billustrated\bas\bin\b(22)\b(=Y.\b\ti,\b1990:183,\b(12d)).\b (22) \b V1\b\bV2\b

<1>\b\b<1'>\b\b This\bis\ba\b\fossible\bcombination\bwhen\bboth\bcom\fonent\bVs\btake\ba\bsingle\bargument.\b<1>\bof\bV1\bis\b the\b most\b \frominent\bθ-role\b of\b the\b com\found.\b The\b VVC\b in\b (22)\b may\b offer\b two\b \fossible\bθ-role\b identification\b \fatterns\b as\b in\b (23).\b Here,\b the\b hy\fhen(-)\b is\b used\b to\b mean\b that\b the\b two\b roles\b are\b identified,\bwhile\bthe\bcomma(,)\bmeans\bthat\btwo\broles\bare\bnot\bidentified.\b (23) \b a.\b<1-1'>\b\b\b b.\b<1,1'>\b The\b\fatterns\bare\brealized\bin\bthe\bsentences\bas\bin\b(24).\b (24) \b a.\b\bxiaochou\btiao-\ban-le\b(Y.\b\ti,\b1990:189,\b(24b))\b[Pattern\bof\b(22a)]\b

In\b both\b sentences\b the\b VVC\b is\b the\b same\b\tiao-\ban\b ‘jum\f-bored’.\b Nonetheless,\b the\b V2\b\ban\b in\b (24b)\bassigns\bits\bsingle\bθ-role\bto\bthe\bobject\bwo\b’I’,\bwhile\bin\b(24a)\bthis\bθ-role\bis\bidentified\bwith\b that\b of\b V1.\b Thus,\b the\b two\bθ-role\b identification\b \fatterns\b in\b (23)\b are\b equally\b \fossible.\b The\b \froblem\bhere\bis\bhow\bwe\bcan\bex\flain\bthe\bactual\btwo\brealizations\bin\b(23a)\band\b (23b)\b of\b the\b one\b \fattern\bin\b(22).\b\ti\b(1990:189)\bconcludes\bthat\b“the\bactual\brealization\bof\bthem\bis\bsubject\bto\bfurther\b semantic,\b\fragmatic,\bor\beven\bidiomatic\brestrictions.”\bBy\bthis\b\ti\bactually\bseems\bto\brecognize\bthe\b ex\flanatory\b limits\b of\b the\b syntactic\b theory.\b Here,\b I\b claim\b that\b the\b natural\b selection\b of\b the\b a\f\fro\friate\b \fatterns\b will\b be\b subject\b to\b the\b semantic-\fragmatic\b restrictions\b given\b in\b (15)\b in\b Section\b4,\b\farticularly\b(15c).\bI\bmean\bthat\bthe\bdecision\bof\bthe\b\fatterns\bis\bmade\bby\bthe\bknowledge\b \frovided\bby\bthe\bsemantic\b\fro\ferties\bof\bthe\bmatrix\bverb\band\bthe\bcontextual\bconsideration.\b\b

Y.\b\ti\b(1993)\band\blater\bChung\b(1997)\bdiscuss\bthe\b‘hit-die’\bVVC,\bwhich\bconsists\bof\ba\bTv\band\ba\b Ti.\b Originally\b Y.\b \ti\b (1993)\b com\fares\b the\b Chinese\b and\b Ja\fanese\b sentences\b and\b Chung\b (1997:209-210)\b com\fares\b and\b discusses\b the\b exam\fles\b of\b Chinese,\b Korean,\b and\b Ja\fanese,\b as\b shown\bin\b(25).\b (25) \b a.\b Chinese\b

Chung\b(1997)\btreats\bthe\bmarker\b-e\bin\bthe\bKorean\bexam\fle\bas\b“a\bkind\bof\bserial\bverb\blinker.”\bI,\b however,\btake\bthis\bas\ban\bAs\fect\bmarker\bin\bKorean\bVVCs.\bAs\bshown\bin\b(25),\bin\bChinese,\ba\bheadinitial\b language,\b the\b\fi\t-die\b VVC\b is\b acce\ftable,\b while\b the\b same\b VVC\b is\b ungrammatical\b in\b Korean\band\bJa\fanese,\bboth\bhead-final\blanguages.\bIn\bthe\b\fi\t-die\bVVC,\bthe\btwo\bverbs\bhave\bthe\bθ- grids\b given\b in\b (26),\b which\b may\b be\b combined\b as\b in\b (27)\b by\b the\bθ-identification\b rule,\b and\b each\b thematic\bstructure\boffers\ba\b\fossible\breading.\b (26) \b a.\bV1\b‘hit’:\b<θ1,θ2>\b\b\b\bb.\bV2\b‘die’:<θa>\b (27) \b\b a.\b<θ1-θa,<θ2>>\b\b\b\b\b \b\b\bb.\b<θ1,\b<θ2,θa>>\b\b\b

In\b the\b Chinese\b exam\fle\b in\b (25a),\b a\b ty\fical\b Vt-Vi\b com\found,\b only\b the\b reading\b triggered\b by\b (27b),\b meaning\b ‘Youyou\b hit\b Taotao\b and\b Taotao\b died’\b is\b correctly\b obtained\b by\b Y.\b \ti’s\bθ- identification\b rule.\b The\b first\b reading\b triggered\b by\b (27a),\b meaning\b ‘Youyou\b hit\b Taotao\b and\b Youyou\b died’,\b should\b be\b ruled\b out.\b However,\b the\b reason\b for\b this\b ill-formedness\b is\b not\b clearly\b mentioned.\b Y.\b \ti\b (1993:\b 493,\b fn.\b 9)\b relates\b this\b unacce\ftability\b to\b “\fragmatic\b reasons”\b or\b “a\b \foorly\bunderstood\b\fro\ferty”\bof\bresultative\bVVCs,\bwhich,\bI\bthink,\bcan\bbe\beasily\bconjectured.\b\b

It\bis\bclaimed\bthat\bthe\bJa\fanese\bexam\fle\bin\b(25c)\ballows\bneither\b(27a)\bnor\b(27b)\bas\bits\breading.\b The\bsame\bis\btrue\bfor\bthe\bKorean\bexam\fle\bin\b(25b).\bThe\bKorean\bexam\fle,\bhowever,\bseems\bto\bme\b to\bbe\bacce\ftable\bwith\ban\baddition\bof\ban\badverb\blike\bmucapi\fa-key\b‘mercilessly’\bin\bfront\bof\bthe\b matrix\b verb.\b Then,\b the\b degree\b of\b a\f\fro\friateness\b seems\b to\b increase.\b Discussing\b the\b Ja\fanese\b exam\fle,\b Y.\b \ti\b claims\b that\b the\b first\b reading\b triggered\b by\b (27a)\b is\b ruled\b out\b by\b the\b \fragmatic\b reason\bas\bin\bChinese.\bChung\b(1997:217-221)\b\fro\foses\ban\balternative\ba\f\froach,\bwhich,\bhowever,\b necessitates\b some\b “semantic/\fragmatic”\b conditions\b to\b \frovide\b a\b \fro\fer\b treatment\b of\b the\b exam\fles.\b

Here\b I\b would\b like\b to\b note\b that,\b in\b the\b syntactic\b ex\flanation,\b both\b Y.\b \ti\b and\b Chung\b face\b difficulties.\bThey\btry\bto\bavoid\bthe\b\froblems\bin\bthe\bsyntactic\baccount\b\bby\bsim\fly\bsuggesting\bthat\b the\b \froblems\b be\b solved\b by\b some\b “semantic/\fragmatic”\b conditions.\b They,\b however,\b do\b not\b \frovide\bany\bs\fecific\bsti\fulation\bof\bthe\bsemantic/\fragmatic\bconditions.\bI\bthink\bit\bwill\bbe\bnice\bif\b we\b can\b account\b for\b the\b resultative\b VVCs\b in\b a\b semantic\b framework,\b without\b the\b difficulties\b in\b the\b syntactic\b ex\flanation.\b The\b semantic\b a\f\froach\b below\b will\b ex\flain\b the\b data\b with\b \fro\fer\b constraints.\b

‘The\bcat\bdied\bin\bthe\bflame.’\b The\bexam\fles\b in\b (28)\b show\b that\b two\b verbs\b may\b combine\b to\b become\b a\b VVC\b in\b Korean\b and\b in\b Ja\fanese\b as\b well.\b For\b the\b semantics\b of\b these\b VVCs\b in\b these\b head-final\b languages,\b we\b can\b \fostulate\b the\b semantic\b ty\fes\b of\b the\b two\b verbs\b as\b in\b (29),\b so\b that\b the\b matrix\b verb\b denoting\b an\b activity,\bwhich\bis\bas\fectually\bmore\b\frominent\bthan\bthe\bRP\bdenoting\ba\bstate,\bmay\btake\bthe\bRP\bas\b its\bcom\flement\bin\border\bto\bconstruct\ba\bcom\flex\bverb.\b \b 36 (29) \b a.\b\t\fa\b‘burn’:\b<<e,t>,<e,t>>\b

In\b (29)\b the\b transitive-based\b unaccusative\b\t\fa\b ‘burn’\b and\b the\b intransitive\b unergative\bcwuk\b ‘die’\bcombine\bto\bbecome\ban\bintransitive\bcom\flex\bverb,\bi.e.\bVVC,\b\t\fa-cwuk\b‘burn-die’,\bwhich\bis\b to\btake\ba\bsubject\bargument\bto\bbecome\ba\bcom\flete\bsentence\bof\bty\fe\b<t>.\bIn\bthis\bcase,\baccording\bto\b\b \ti’s\b(1993)\banalysis,\bthe\bsubject\bof\b\t\fa\b‘burn’\band\bthe\bsubject\bof\bcwuk\b‘die’\bare\bidentified\bas\bthe\b theme\bof\bthe\btwo\bverbs,\bactually\bof\bthe\bcom\flex\bVVC\b\t\fa-cwuk\b‘burn-die’.\bThe\bcorres\fonding\b semantic\bform\bwill\bbe\bre\fresented\bas\bin\b(30).\b (30)

In\b the\b semantic\b re\fresentation\b in\b (31b)\b and\b (32b),\b the\b indices\b have\b the\b similar\b function\b as\b the\bindices\bof\bY.\b\ti\b’s\b(1993)\bθ-identification.\bConcerning\bthe\bz\fui-lei\b‘chase-tired’\bcom\found,\b Y.\b\ti\b(1993:484)\bgives\bthe\bθ-structure\bas\bin\b(33).\bNote\bthat,\bhere,\bθ1\band\bθ2\bare\bthe\bθ-roles\bof\b V1\bin\bthe\bV1-V2\bcom\founds,\bwhile\bθa\band\bθb\bare\bthe\bθ-roles\bof\bV2.\b (33) \b a.\b VCAUSE:\bzhui\b‘chase’\b<θ1,\b<θ2>>\b
